Another common variable in programming is called a boolean, which can have either the value “true” or “false”. We can use this to evaluate different conditions; for example, if you want to know if the number x=1 is equal to the number 2, the expression x==2 would return the boolean value “false”. However, the statement x<3 would return “true”. This is extremely valuable when you only want to call a method only if a certain condition is satisfied, and do something else if it’s not. Consider the following example: name=Mark age=21 if name==Mark and age==21: print “My name is Mark; I’m 21 years old” elif name!=Mark and age==21: print “My name isn’t Mark; I’m 21 years old.” else: print “My name isn’t Mark and I’m not 21 years old.” We only call certain methods if the conditions specified in the if statement before them are satisfied. Try this on your own- you will pick up an unknown item from a box using the method get_in_front().take_item(). If the item is an axe, say “I got something sharp”. If it’s a wand, say “I got something magical”, and if it’s a tomato, “I got something red”.
